reasoning: Crucial because the paper’s central claim (“no easy eutopia”) leans heavily on a multiplicative fragility picture; learning that effective N is small or that dimensions are highly correlated would substantially weaken the conclusion and shift priorities toward generic prosperity/governance, while large N with weak correlations strengthens the case for targeted multi-domain value work. Highly paper-specific: it directly interrogates Sec. 2.4’s product-of-factors model and its implied rarity of mostly-great futures. Moderately tractable: you can operationalise via eliciting evaluations of many future-world vignettes across many moral views and fitting latent-factor/correlation models, but results will be sensitive to how you sample moral views, specify vignettes, elicit cardinal values, and define “value-critical,” so strong conclusions are hard. Clarity is decent but not perfect because “effective N,” “near-independent,” and the relevant dependence structure require methodological choices (factor model class, identifiability, what counts as a dimension vs subdimension). Decision hook is explicit and strong. Dead weight is low: most text supports the question and its strategic relevance.
title: Effective dimensionality of value-critical moral failure modes
